summary: Book Challenge: To Kill A Mockingbird challenged for Intolerance
notes: A parent made formal request to remove To Kill a Mockingbird from the curriculum, citing 28 racial slurs directed at African American characters. The book was ultimately retained.

summary: Book Challenge: The Facts Speak for Themselves challenged for Sex
notes: Parents requested the removal of Brock Cole's The Facts Speak for Themselves from the school library due to the book's use of sexually explicit language. Book was apparently removed from the school library without a review process.

summary: Book Challenge: The Hate U Give challenged for Profanity
notes: Angie Thomas's The Hate U Give was pulled mid-instruction from middle school classrooms after a staff member complained about profanity. The book had never been officially approved for classroom use.

summary: Book Challenge: The Giver challenged for Dark Themes
notes: A formal request was submitted to remove The Giver from the curriculum because of references to homicide and sexuality.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student punished for Political/Social Views
notes: A middle student was physically forced to his feet and made to leave the classroom when he chose to not stand for the Pledge of Allegiance, despite 80 years of Supreme Court jurisprudence rendering that unlawful.. A district spokesperson later confirmed that students have the right to decline to participate in the Pledge

summary: Book Challenge: The Hate U Give challenged for Profanity
notes: The Hate U Give was assigned as a supplemental text to Reed Academy eighth-graders until a parent requested it be removed due to profanity. A Missouri State Representative Anderson also contacted school officials to request the book's removal, citing the same concerns. Consequently, the book was pulled from the classroom, pending further review of its educational merits.

summary: Book Challenge: Looking for Alaska challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: A challenge was filed to Looking for Alaska by John Green in the High School English curriculum

summary: Book Challenge: A Separate Peace challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: A Separate Peace, by John Knowles was abruptly pulled (without prior review) from a Prosper High School English classroom, in response to parental objections to the book's discussion of sexuality

summary: Book Challenge: To Kill A Mockingbird challenged for Intolerance
notes: To Kill a Mockingbird and The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn were removed from the curriculum without review or teacher input, in violation of district policy

summary: Event/Other Expression: Students censored for Political/Social Views
notes: A Superintendent sent a letter to families and also posted it on social media warning that anyone protesting gun violence [in response to the Parkland, FL school shooting] would face being punished with a 3-day out of school suspension.

summary: Internet/Social Media: District censored comments on its Facebook page for Criticism of School
notes: A school district removed comments from the district's Facebook page which disagreed with the District's position on student protests.

summary: Book Challenge: Perks of Being a Wallflower challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: A challenge to The Perks of Being a Wallflower by Stephen Chbosky sought its removal from middle and high school classrooms and libraries.

summary: Book Challenge: Looking for Alaska challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: Looking for Alaska by John Green was removed from middle school libraries, without formal review as required by district regulations

summary: Book Challenge: Two Boys Kissing challenged for Sex
notes: A school board removed Tanya Lee Stone's A Bad Boy Can Be Good for a Girl, against the recommendation of the review committee

summary: Event/Other Expression: Students censored for LGBTQ content
notes: Performance of the student- authored play Confessions at a high school was halted because of a Catholic teacher's objections to the depiction of a homosexual priest.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored ffor Political/Social Views
notes: A high school student wearing a T-shirt with a pro-Trump message was told by an assistant principal to either cover his shirt or leave campus. The student chose to leave and later found out that his absence was being recorded as a suspension. The school later rescinded the suspension.

summary: Book Challenge: Fun Home challenged for Sex
notes: Parents sought removal of Fun Home from the 12th grade curriculum due to its =E2=80=9Csexually explicit nature.=E2=80=9D

summary: Event/Other Expression: Valedictorian's speech censored for Criticism of School
notes: High School valedictorian was told by school officials not to talk about her alleged on-campus sexual assault and that the school took no action when she reported it during her graduation speech. Her microphone was turned off when she started talking about those topics.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for Political/Social Views
notes: One of six valedictorians chose not to speak at graduation after the administration censored her speech which referenced discrimination, school shootings, and gender inequality.

summary: Book Challenge: The Hate U Give challenged for Political/Social Views
notes: The inclusion of two popular young adult books, The Hate U Give by Angie Thomas and All American Boys by Jason Reynolds and Brendan Kiely, on the Wando High School summer reading list was challenged by the local Fraternal Order of Police in Charleston County, South Carolina.

summary: Art/Display: Student artwork censored for Political/Social Views
notes: A recent high school graduate was made to alter - twice - a painting that bore the name of her alleged rapist, before the school removed it from being on display in one of the school's hallways.

summary: Press/Yearbook: School attempted to censor school newspaper for Criticism of School
notes: As a result of advocacy and national Press/Yearbook coverage, the principal of Prosper High School informed the student journalists of the Eagle Nation Online that they would not need his approval before publishing. This is a reversal of a policy the principal put in place during the 2017-2018 school year which required stories be submitted and approved by him and also banned student opinion pieces.

summary: Art/Display: Religious groups called for removal of LGBTQ content from book display at library
notes: Local religious groups called for the removal of all LGBTQ books from a Banned Books Week display at the Rumford Public Library.

summary: Art/Display: Student art was removed for Political/Social views
notes: Two Black Lives Matter chalk drawings, created by students participating in a fundraiser, were removed, as directed by the school principal, for being controversial.

summary: Book Challenge: City of Thieves challenged for Sex
notes: City of Thieves, by David Benioff, was removed from a10th grade English class pending review, in violation of district policy

summary: Book Challenge: Beartown challenged for Sex
notes: School district removed Beartown, a 2017 novel by Fredrik Backman. The school board's decision to ban the book followed an influx of parent complaints. The book had been assigned in a 10th grade honors English class until parents complained about its =E2=80=9Cvulgar=E2=80=9D, =E2=80=9Cgraphic=E2=80=9D and =E2=80=9Cjust unnecessary=E2=80=9D subject matter.

summary: Press/Yearbook: School newspaper censored for Criticism of School
notes: A student newspaper published a story which questioned the legitimacy of the district's approval for five varsity football players to transfer mid-school year from one high school to another. Despite there being Arkansas state laws protecting the rights of student publications and the right of expression of student journalists, demands were made by district officials to remove the story from the newspaper's website. The Herald was also suspended from publishing while the district rewrites the policies and protocols for student-run publications.

summary: Book Challenge: I Am Jazz challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: Challenges to three books with transgender protagonists on "moral grounds"

summary: Book Challenge: Fun Home challenged for Sex
notes: Fun Home was removed from a school library.

summary: Book Challenge: Assassination Classroom challenged for Violence
notes: Assassination Classroom was removed from a school library.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student punished for Political/Social Views
notes: When a sixth-grade student at Lawton Chiles Middle Academy refused to stand for the Pledge of Allegiance, the substitute teacher called the school administration. An administrator and school resource officer came and asked the student to leave the classroom. The district claims the substitute teacher did not know the student code of conduct doesn't mandate participation during the Pledge of Allegiance.

summary: Book Challenge: It's Perfectly Normal challenged for Sex
notes: A challenge was filed  to Its Perfectly Normal

summary: Book Challenge: Pride: The Story of Harvey Milk and the Rainbow Flag challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: PRIDE

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for Political/Social Views
notes: A sixth-grade student was told that she could not use then-President Trump for her hero's project because he "spreads negativity and says bad stuff about women".

summary: Book Challenge: Eleanor & Park challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: Eleanor and Park, by Rainbow Rowell, was pulled from the 8th grade Battle of the Books choice curriculum without review.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student play censored for Profanity, Sex and Intolerance
notes: A middle school production of "The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee" was cancelled after the play was "deemed more appropriate for high school and not middle school". The district raised concerns including profane language, sexual innuendo, and potentially-viewed-as-racist lines. Ultimately, a solution was found (by a student) and the play will go on - with a delayed start and PG-13 rating, noting mature content.

summary: Press/Yearbook: Students censored for Sex
notes: After a CA school district sought to censor an article in the school newspaper about an 18-year-old student who works in the adult entertainment industry in order pay bills, an attorney hired by the district informed the district that the censorship was illegal under California law, which gives student journalist broad free expression Press/Yearbook rights. The article subsequently appeared in the school newspaper.

summary: Art/Display: Mural removed for  LGBTQ content
school_district: Bergen Arts & Science Charter High School
notes: A charter school removed an LGBTQ pride mural that a sixteen year old student had made. The school's landlord, a church, complained that the mural's rainbow heart was "offensive".

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored for Political/Social Views
notes: A student's yearbook photo was airbrushed to remove the words on his hat, "Trump

summary: Event/Other Expression: Author book talk cancelled for Sex
notes: A book talk with author Elizabeth Acevedo at Buck Lodge Middle School was cancelled after a county official objected to passages in her young-adult novel With the Fire on High.

summary: Art/Display: Student artwork censored for Sex
school_district: Mill River Unified Union School District
notes: A student's art project was barred from the District's Advanced Placement art showcase. The project featured pictures of persons tied using Shibari, a form artistic Japanese rope bondage. The principal had received complaints from students saying the piece made them uncomfortable and was offensive.

summary: Book Challenge: The Walking Dead challenged for Violence and Profanity
notes: The Walking Dead was removed from school despite a review committee recommendation to keep it.

summary: Book Challenge: Love Is Love challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: The LGBTQ anthology comic book Love is Love was removed from a high school without undergoing a proper review process. It is also unclear who authorized the removal of the book from the school.

summary: Art/Display: Student artwork censored for Political/Social Views
notes: A piece of student artwork, hung on display during the 2016-2017 school year, depicting then-President Trump with tape over his mouth and the Statue of Liberty covering her face was removed from the hallway at a high school The district stated that the artwork was removed "not due to any attention on social media, but because the principal received a threatening phone call. This decision was made in the interest of safety..."

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored for LGBTQ content
notes: After a female student chose to wear a tuxedo for her senior portrait instead of the traditional black velvet drape and pearls often worn by females, the yearbook omitted her picture and instead listed her name on the back page under the heading "Not Pictured".

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Students censored for Political/Social Views
notes: Several high school students who were wearing LGBTQ pride shirts were charged with a dress code violation. The students were forced to change shirts.

summary: Book Challenge: Dear Martin challenged for Sex
notes: Three novels were excluded from the Columbia County High School supplemental curriculum based on isolated references to sex, violence or =E2=80=9Cgraphic depictions=E2=80=9D

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for various reasons
notes: Challenges to books in Diverse Classroom Libraries led to books being retained but moved to different grade levels. The books were

summary: Press/Yearbook: School newspaper censored for Criticism of School
notes: A high school newspaper was censored after the paper planned to run a story about a special needs student causing constant classroom disruptions, including punching a teacher in the head, resulting in a concussion The state has a New Voices Act which provides additional student Press/Yearbook freedom beyond that granted by the US Constitution.

summary: Book Challenge: Prince and Knight challenged for LGBTQ content and Sex
notes: Prince & Knight removed from the children's section of library at the request of a local pastor.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Students censored for LGBTQ content
notes: Students reported that the school rejected the students' request to start an LGBTQ support club and refused to use a student's preferred pronouns.

summary: Art/Display: Student art destroyed by teacher for Political/Social Views
notes: After four elementary school students chose "Black Lives Matter" as the subject for their "activism artwork" assignment, their teacher reportedly threw away their artwork claiming it was "inappropriate and political".

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student Censored for LGBTQ Content
notes: A sixth grade student was prohibited from doing her "real world problems" project on the topic of LGBTQ pride.

summary: Press/Yearbook: Students censored for Religion
notes: Student journalists decided to keep the first page of the school newspaper blank after they were told to replace the original photo, one of a Christmas tree ornament with the words "I love Jesus", with something else.

summary: Book Challenge: It's Perfectly Normal Challenged for Sex
notes: State Representative Kelly Townsend wrote a Facebook post calling for public school and county libraries to pull copies of It's Perfectly Normal from their shelves. The local library refused.

summary: Book Challenge: George challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: A principal contacted us looking for guidance re

summary: Internet/Social Media: Student punished for Intolerance
notes: A student posted a sentence in Hebrew on his snapchat, which translates to "if you can read this you are cancer." The student claimed it was a joke. After the district received complaints from students and parents, the student was suspended for 10 days and given notice of intent to expel under the following provisions of the Rules of Conduct

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student punished for Political/Social Views and Intolerance
notes: A student was punished for having images of the Confederate flag on campus. School policy says that the district forbids images which "Could be offensive or have a "double meaning," including references to death or violence (such as guns or deadly weapons), or Confederate flag items." School does not claim risk of disruption, only that flag is pro-slavery / offensive. The school denied that any student has been punished and says they have "no responsive documents" other than the student handbook and district policy.

summary: Art/Display: Student punished for Intolerance
notes: Student was disciplined for creating an allegedly racist meme, but most discipline was subsequently reversed.

summary: Press/Yearbook: Yearbook senior quotes removed for Criticism of School
notes: Yearbook decided to include senior quotes. Administration said the quotes submitted by students were too controversial, and told yearbook students that they could not include any quote about race, sexuality, or anything negative about schools. One quote was deemed inappropriate simply because a girl talked about the fact she was gay. The school eventually decreed that senior quotes would not be allowed in the book at all. Referred to SPLC

summary: Book Challenge: Little & Lion challenged for Sex and LGBTQ content
notes: Parents asked the School Board to pull Little & Lion from its approved list of reading materials. They said they are going to pursue a formal complaint, but the district states that no formal complaint was filed.

summary: Internet/Social Media: Student punished for Criticism of School on social media
notes: A student was removed from the Choir Presidency after she posted a video in retaliation to being anonymously bullied on Snapchat. They told her that she was terrible at her job and they hated choir because of her. In her video she didn't name names however she did use the =E2=80=9Cf=E2=80=9D word and basically said she didn't care what they thought and she was going to be her and do the best job she knew how in so many words.

summary: Internet/Social Media: Student censored for Intolerance
notes: A student posted a picture on Instagram and the principal told him to take it down. The picture was of a white kid giving another white kid a paper with "n-word pass" written on it - the point being that the recipient gets to use the word.

summary: Book Challenge: Drama challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: A challenge was filed to Drama, because it "normalizes" LGBTQ identity. The book was ultimately retained.

summary: Book Challenge: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings challenged for Sex and Violence
notes: A school district banned I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings for all students, one day before the start of a unit featuring the book. The book is on the text exemplar list for the state of Mississippi and the district has approved lesson plans on it for 7 years for tenth grade English. One parent had complained tabout the molestation scene in chapter 12.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored for Sex
notes: "Virginity Rocks" t-shirt barred from middle school. School district claimed that "the shirt is sexual orientation...Sexual orientation cannot be expressed in school."

summary: Book Challenge: The Bluest Eye challenged for Sex and Violence
notes: The Bluest Eye was removed from an English Language Arts reading list. It had been assigned to AP English. We learned of this after the fact.

summary: Internet/Social Media: Student punished for Political and Social Views and Intolerance
notes: A student was suspended for posting a "Trump 2020" photo with a Confederate flag and swastika on social media.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student punished for Intolerance
notes: Student suspended for "homosexuality is a mental disability" sign presented to LGBTQ kids. The student wants to stage protest outside school with people wearing shirts with that slogan.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored for Political/Social Views
notes: The parents of two high school students sued the school after their sons were told by school administration that they could not wear clothing bearing images of guns as it's a violation of the dress code.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Clothing banned for obstensibly endorsing the use of Drugs/Alcohol
notes: A high school banned a clothing brand called cookies because of its ties to the marijuana industry. The clothing does not depict any type of drug use and is simply a logo saying "Cookies," which is also a brand name of a chain of marijuana dispensaries.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for LGBTQ content
notes: A student was not allowed to write a paper on same sex marriage.

summary: Internet/Social Media Censorship for LGBTQ content
notes: School internet blocked websites related to LGBTQ content under the label of Alternate Lifestyle. Sites such as gaytimes.co.uk and lambda.org were completely blocked.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for Criticism of School
school_district: Central Community School of Elkader, Iowa
notes: Student was blocked from commenting on their school's Facebook page.

summary: Internet/Social Media: School internet blocks sites related to Religion
notes: A public school censored internet access, including the websites of the Vatican, Jewish learning sites, sites about Islam, Red State, Refuse Fascism, and Reason.

summary: Book Challenge: Various challenged for Sex and Profanity
notes: A district removed five "controversial" books from 11th grade English reading list

summary: Internet/Social Media: Student punished for Intolerance
notes: A school investigated after a student posted a racist video online.

summary: Internet/Social Media: Student punished for Intolerance
notes: A student who used the N-word on social media was threatened with expulsion

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for Political/Social Views
notes: A valedictorian's speech was cut short just before she said "no justice, no peace." The district claims it was inadvertent.

summary: Internet/Social Media: Students punished for  Political/Social Views and Intolerance
notes: After six members of a high school cheer team were seen in a photo on social media posing with an image of the Confederate flag, attempts were made to have the school administration punish the teens.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student punished for Criticism of School
notes: A high school sophomore was suspended for posting a photo she took of the virtually maskless, crowded halls of her high school, during the height of COVID. The suspension was lifted after the photo went viral, leading to criticism and support from free speech groups.

summary: Book Challenge: Something Happened in Our Town: A Child's Story About Racial Injustice challenged for Anti-Police content
notes: Teachers were informed that they are not allowed to read or talk about the book Something Happened in Our Town

summary: Book Challenge: Fun Home challenged for Sex
notes: A parents association challenged the use of the book Fun Home by Alison Bechdel, in a 10th grade Honors English class, because of alleged sexual violence, drug use, and anti-religious sentiments. The group has already held a press conference with local law makers stating the teacher is "flouting" the law regarding distribution of obscene material to children.

summary: Book Challenge: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn and others challenged for Intolerance
notes: District removed several novels in its curriculum that include racial slurs, including To Kill A Mockingbird, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, The Cay, and Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored for Sex
notes: A fifth-grade student was told during his gym class that he could not wear his Hooter's face mask in class because it was "deemed offensive".

summary: Book Challenge: Ghost Boys challenged for Anti-Police content
notes: A challenge ws filed to the use of Ghost Boys in a 5th Grade class, because it is ostensibly anti-police.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for Political/Social Views
notes: A teacher threatened to remove a 16-year-old student from his virtual class if he didn't remove a flag reading "Trump 2020", from his background.

summary: Book Challenge: All American Boys challenged for Sex and Anti-Police content
notes: Parents challenged All American Boys. District policy requires book to be removed pending outcome of formal complaint. We wrote to the district to suggest reforms to their challenge policies

summary: Book Challenge: The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian challenged for Sex
notes: Parent challenged Absolutely True Diary of a Part Time Indian. Teachers were told to stop teaching it. District memo says that the book has been pulled, pending investigation.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student was punished for Intolerance
notes: In response to the Superintendent sending out a school community-wide email that the OK hand symbol was racist and not allowed, a student wore a t-shirt with the image of President Obama giving the OK hand sign. The student was suspended.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored for Religion
notes: A third-grade student was forced to remove her mask with the saying "Jesus loves me" because school policy states that masks cannot display political, religious, sexual or any inappropriate symbols, gestures or statements that may be offensive, disruptive or deemed distractive to the school environment.

summary: Book Challenge: Scholastic News challenged for Political/Social Views
notes: A school district cancelled its subscription to Scholastic News Journal after a parent complained that an editorial was biased against President Trump.

summary: Book Challenge: Stamped: Racism, Antiracism, and You challenged for Political/Social Views
notes: Parent challenged Stamped by Jason Reynolds in 8th grade ELA. Committee voted unanimously to keep the book before we could take action.

summary: Book Challenge: History of US challenged for Intolerance
notes: The textbook, A History of US, was removed after allegations that it was racist.

summary: Book Challenge: Slaughterhouse Five challenged for Sex and Profanity
notes: A challenge was filed to the use of Slaugherhouse Five in AP English class

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Intolerance
notes: The entire list of books, documentary films, and articles compiled in August 2020 by the Central York School District's diversity committee was removed that November by the district's school board, pending a review. In the fall of 2021, after a principal reminded teachers not to use the books, students campaigned for the books to be restored. ON September 20, 2021, the school board temporarily reversed their initial decision as the materials on the list undergo a review.

summary: Book Challenge: Various challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: LGBTQ books were moved from the children's section of public library.

summary: Book Challenge: Of Mice and Men and Montana 1948 challenged for Intolerance
school_district: West St. Paul-Mendota Heights-Eagan Area Schools (SD 197)
notes: Of Mice and Men (racist language) and Montana 1948 (depictions of Native Americans) were removed from high school. A district spokeswoman said the book complaints have highlighted a need for the district to develop a policy for reconsidering instructional materials. We sent our challenge procedure guidelines

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student censored for Political/Social Views and Intolerance
notes: A high school student was barred from wearing a mask depicting the Confederate flag to school.

summary: Book Challenge: Persepolis challenged for Sex and Violence
school_district: Half Hollow Hills Central School Dist
notes: The graphic novel Persepolis was removed from 9th grade classrooms. A group of parents complained about the book and started a change.org petition against the book.

summary: Art/Display: Student art was removed for Political/Social views
notes: School administrators removed the part of a student-created Black History Month mural at a middle school which depicted raised fists - which is both the symbol for Black Lives Matter and the universal symbol for solidarity. The district stated that the removed art was "perceived as politically controversial" and "unrelated to the educational purpose of Black History Month".

summary: Press/Yearbook: Students censored for LGBTQ content
notes: A high school principal told the yearbook that a 2-page spread "Loud & Proud", which chronicles LGBTQ+ students' experiences, could not be included in the yearbook, despite the fact that the Arkansas Student Publications Act gives student journalists added protection against administrative censorship.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student punished for LGBTQ content
notes: A girl was banned from school bus for saying "I'm a lesbian".

summary: Press/Yearbook: Student censored for LGBTQ content
notes: After an elementary school principal rejected a fourth-grade student's essay on transgender equality from appearing in a school publication, the parents of the child sued the school. The court ruled in favor of the school because given the grounds for the removal, i.e., that it was "not age appropriate," rendered the removal permissible under the Supreme Court's Hazelwood decision, which permits censorship of student speech in school-sponsored publication if the decision is based on legitimate pedagogical concerns.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex, Violence and Dark Themes
notes: A school district reviewed a list of 120 books on a diverse titles list used for independent reading by students. Several books were ultimately removed after a lengthy review by committees of stakeholders, but the vast majority were retained.

summary: Book Challenge: Call Me Max challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: A teacher distributed a list of reading resources, one of which was re a transgender child. After protests, the district told the teacher not to use the book, Call Me Max.

summary: Book Challenge: The Poet X challenged for Sex
notes: A challenge was filed to The Poet X for classroom use. We sent challenge procedure guidelines, because the district's policies are inadequate

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student punished for Criticism of School
notes: A student was disciplined for circulating a survey re COVID rules at school.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Students censored for Protest
notes: South Sioux City Community Schools banned all student protest.

summary: Book Challenge: Ghost Boys challenged for Anti-Police content
notes: Ghost Boys was removed from classroom use because it is ostensibly anti-police.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Students punished for Political/Social Views
notes: Two elementary school students, aged 8 and 5, were removed from their classrooms for wearing T-shirts which read "Black Lives Matter". The district claimed that the shirts created the risk of "a disturbance in the school."

summary: Internet/Social Media: Student punished for Intolerance
notes: A Fairfield Warde High School student was arrested after posting a picture on social media which contained a racial slur aimed at a black classmate who was also in the photo.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Students punished for Intolerance
notes: A high school chapter of Turning Point USA was disbanded after it displayed a poster saying, "China kinda sus [i.e., suspect or questionable]," had been approved by school administration. This led to accusations of racism from students and local politicians.

summary: Book Challenge: One Of A Kind Like Me/Único Como Yo challenged for LGBTQ content
notes: After local university students performed the book One of a Kind, Like Me for elementary school students via video, some parents complained to district officials. In response, the district superintendent apologized for not ensuring that the book was vetted before being performed, and a school board member was quoted as saying that the district does not consider matters of =E2=80=9Cgender identity politics=E2=80=9D to be appropriate for the district's elementary school classrooms. The book tells the story of a boy who decides to dress as a princess for a school costume parade.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for LGBTQ content
notes: A teacher took away a middle school student's Pride flag during a class picture.

summary: Clothing/Appearance: Student punished for Political/Social Views
notes: A student's receipt of his diploma was delayed after he wore a Mexican flag over his graduation gown at his school's graduation ceremony. in violation of the ceremony's dress code.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Intolerance. A private school teacher was criticized for not disciplining students for using rap song with N-word
notes: A teacher was criticized for not disciplining students for using rap song with N-word in CA private school.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student censored for LGBTQ content
school_district: Eastern Camden County Regional School District
notes: A high school valedictorian had his commencement speech cut off after he told the audience he came out as queer during freshman year. The student gave the speech in lieu of the speech that had been approved by the school administration, which did not mention sexual orientation.

summary: Book Challenge: Persepolis and others challenged for Sex
notes: Monday's Not Coming By Tiffany D. Jackson. Persepolis

summary: Press/Yearbook: Students censored for Political/Social Views
notes: School officials removed a two-page spread in the yearbook following publication. The spread outlined important world events that took place during the 2020-2021 academic year, including the 2020 election, the impact of COVID-19, the death of George Floyd, and more. The reason cited for the removal of the already-published content was that school officials were at the receiving end of =E2=80=9Ccommunity backlash=E2=80=9D over the yearbook spread.

summary: Art/Display: Student mural was removed for Political/Social views
school_district: New York City Dept of Education
notes: A student mural was removed from a Brooklyn elementary school after complaint that is was divisive because of elements related to Black Lives Matter

summary: Book Challenge: Lawn Boy challenged for Sex
notes: A challenge was filed to Lawn Boy (available in school library) because it ostensibly depicts sex between children. A parent also filed a police report, alleging that the book is child pornography or obscenity

summary: Book Challenge: 642 Things to Write About challenged for Sex and Violence
notes: Book of writing prompts in a college course taught at local high school to HS students was removed due to "inappropriate" topics being included therein.

summary: Book Challenge: Out of Darkness challenged for Sex
notes: Out of Darkness, by Ashley Hope P=C3=A9rez, was removed from the libraries of two middle schools after a complaint, despite district policy requiring that challenged materials remain available while challenge is pending.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer and Lawn Boy challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer, by Maia Kobabe, and Lawn Boy=E2=80=9D, by Jonathan Evison, were pulled from circulation pending adjudication of a challenge. District policy allows up to 120 work days to conclude all levels of adjudication.

summary: Book Challenge: It's Perfectly Normal challenged for Sex
notes: Parents protested at Cass County Public Library Board of Trustees meeting regarding presence of Its Perfectly Normal by Robie Harris.

summary: Art/Display: Mural removed from high school library for Political/Social Views
notes: High school students staged a schoolwide walkout to protest the removal of Claudia Corcoran's artwork from the library. The two-panel anti-racism painting was removed after the school received complaints from students, parents, and faculty.

summary: Book Challenge: New Kid and its sequel Class Act challenged for Political/Social Views and Intolerance
notes: School district removed library books by Jerry Kraft pending adjudication of parent complaint they are pro-CRT.

summary: Book Challenge: Our Skin: A First Conversation About Race challenged for Political/Social Views
notes: The Westfield Board of Education accepted the recommendation of an internal committee tasked with deciding on a parent's formal complaint about the use of the book, =E2=80=9COur Skin

summary: Book Challenge: The Breakaways challenged for LGBTQ
notes: The Breakaways was removed from elementary school libraries after a district committee upheld a challenge.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex, and Political/Social Views
notes: School district removed library books pending adjudication of a Board member complaint. The books included A Lesson Before Dying by Ernest Gaines, The Bluest Eye by Toni Morrison, and Lawn Boy by Jonathan Evison.

summary: Book Challenge: Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe challenged for Profanity and Drug/Alcohol use
notes: Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe was removed from a classroom library. Its use falls under school's controversial issues policy, which requires controversial materials which have not been officially adopted to be approved by the principal.

summary: Book Challenge: The Poet X challenged for Sex
notes: The superintendent pulled The Poet X from the New Kent Middle School library after a parent complained that it contained inappropriate content. The district's challenge polices are very minimal, so we contacted the district to suggest improvements

summary: Book Challenge: Fun Home challenged for Sex
school_district: North Hunterdon-Voorhees Regional High School District
notes: A challenge committee reviewed Alison Bechdel's Fun Home, Jonathan Evison's Lawn Boy, Gender Queer by Maia Kobabe, and This Book is Gay by Juno Dawson. The review committee began meeting, despite the fact that no librarian has been appointed to the committee, in contravention of Board regulations.

summary: Book Challenge: Ghost Boys challenged for Anti-Police content
notes: Ghost Boys was paused as a recommended reading based on the complaints of a few parents, until the district develops a policy regarding adopting supplementary materials. We sent advice and challenge guidelines.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer was removed from high school libraries after a review committee recommended removal.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: One parent challenged Gender Queer at a board meeting, and another parent filed a police report in connection to the book, alleging it was pornography in school.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer and All American Boys have been challenged. The Supt informed us that the District is following policy.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex and Dark Themes
notes: The Lindbergh Board of Education received an official challenge of 15 books carried in the Lindbergh High School library. The books were mostly chosen for mentions of sex and suicide. The challenge was the focus of most public comment at the board's Oct. 21 meeting, with some citizens in support and opposition of a possible ban.

summary: Book Challenge: Milk and Honey challenged for Sex
notes: Roseburg High School currently faces a challenge to a  book of poetry. =E2=80=9CMilk and Honey=E2=80=9D is by Rupi Kaur, an Indian-Canadian author and social media activist. The book deals with surviving sexual assault as well as empowerment, consent and female sexuality. No student is required to read the book, but for now they can choose to check it out from the library.

summary: Book Challenge: The Absolutely True Story of a Part-time Indian challenged for Sex
notes: A challenge was filed to the use of The Absolutely True Story of a Part-time Indian in a 9th grade English class. Four members of the school board in the district were facing a recall election at thte time. The recall effort has consistently used excerpts from the book in social media, campaign text messages and paid ads to "illustrate" that the district under the current board doing a disservice to students by teaching this book.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex
notes: Three LGBTQ books (All Boys Aren't Blue, Lawn Boy, and Gender Queer) were removed from a high school library lafter a challenge was filed, despite a district policy which says that "Instructional materials shall not be removed or withdrawn from use during the pendency of the review process except upon three-fourths vote of the entire membership of the review committee and approval of the building principal, who shall state compelling reasons in writing for such action."

summary: Book Challenge: Fun Home challenged for Sex
notes: The graphic memoir Fun Home

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer was removed from a district library without following the district's challenge procedure.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Political/Social Views
notes: After a warehouse worker saw a book she thought was regarding Critical Race Theory, and since the Supt had said there is no CRT in the district, the worker reported it up the chain of command. An Assistant Supt ordered the books removed from libraries, despite no challenge being filed and challenge procedures saying they must stay on the shelves. Eventually, a librarian protested, and the books were returned.

summary: Book Challenge: Fun Home and All Boys Aren't Blue challenged for Sex
notes: Fun Home by Alison Bechdel and All Boys Aren't Blue by George M. Johnson were removed pending review, in contravention of district regulations.

summary: Book Challenge: Various challenged for Sex and Violence
notes: A district removed Beyond Magenta, Monday's Not Coming, Out of Darkness, The Bluest Eye,  and Opposite of Innocent pending review, despite board policy requiring books to be retained pending the outcome of challenges.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student play (She Kills Monsters) canceled for Intolerance and Violence
notes: A production of Qui Nguyen's play, She Kills Monsters, was cancelled due to the play's use of =E2=80=9Cinappropriate language, profanity, homophobic slurs, sexual innuendos and graphic violence.=E2=80=9D However, the script being used was the =E2=80=9CYoung Adventurers Version,=E2=80=9D which is a gentler version prepared by the author for children above age 11.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer was removed from a library without following District's challenge procedure.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer was removed from a school library without following the District's challenge procedure.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex, Political/Social Views, and Profanity
notes: A school district removed more than two dozen books from circulation in the district's school libraries, citing national attention and challenges to the books elsewhere. After an outcry, the District reversed its decision.

summary: Book Challenge: 33 Snowfish challenged for Sex
notes: The Spotsylvania County School Board directed staff to begin removing books that contain =E2=80=9Csexually explicit=E2=80=9D material from library shelves and report on the number of books that have been removed at a special called meeting next week. After the Board's attorney opined that the order was unconstitutional, and many parents objected to the order, the order was rescinded.

summary: Art/Display: Student poster removed for Anti-Police content
notes: A poster created by a student was removed from an African American display at Hillsborough Middle School at the direction of a member of the board of education, because it was ostensibly anti-police.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex
notes: South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster requested that the state's Superintendent of Education begin a comprehensive investigation into the presence of obscene and pornographic materials in public schools in South Carolina.  The request was sparked by a challenge to Gender Queer in a local school district

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Profanity and Sex
notes: A parent challenged All Boys Aren't Blue by George Johnson, Gender Queer by Maia Kabobe, Lawn Boy by Jonathan Evison, The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian by Sherman Alexie and Hey, Kiddo by Jarrett Krosoczka. A committee recommended that all of the books be retained.

summary: Book Challenge: All Boys Aren't Blue challenged for Sex
notes: A member of the Flagler County, Florida school board filed a criminal complaint over four copies of All Boys Aren't Blue, an LGBTQ book recommended for 14 to 18 year olds, claiming it violates the state's obscenity laws.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer is going through the District's challenge procedure after a formal complaint was filed

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer was removed from circulation pending the outcome of a challenge.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex
notes: Parents in Howard County, MD, filed criminal complaints alleging that obscene works are present in the county's schools.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Two formal complaints were filed to Gender Queer, leading to large-scale lobbying at school board meeting by adherents on both sides. We offered assistance in reforming district challenge procedures, which were minimal.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: A school district removed several books from district libraries without submitting those books to the District's book challenge procedures, and despite the fact that District policy expressly states that =E2=80=9Caccess to a challenged resource shall not be restricted during the reconsideration process=E2=80=9D

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: Gender Queer was removed from a library w/o following procedure because it was district leadership who challenged the book,and the district claims that its challenge procedure does not apply to challenges brought by administrators.

summary: Book Challenge: The Bluest Eye and  Lawn Boy challenged for Sex
notes: The Wentzville School District temporarily removed =E2=80=9CThe Bluest Eye=E2=80=9D by Toni Morrison and =E2=80=9CLawn Boy=E2=80=9D by Jonathan Evison, pending the outcome of challenges.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer and Where I End And You Begin challenged for Sex
notes: The Rockwood School District conducted formal challenges to remove both =E2=80=9CGender Queer=E2=80=9D by Maia Kobabe and =E2=80=9CWhere I End And You Begin=E2=80=9D by Preston Norton.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex
notes: Five books were challenged at Francis Howell School District

summary: Book Challenge: It's Perfectly Normal challenged for Sex
notes: A formal request was made to remove Its Perfectly Normal from a middle school library

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex
notes: Nine criminal complaints were filed against the school district over the inclusion in school libraries of Gender Queer,=E2=80=9DAll Boys Aren't Blue, George and Lawn Boy.

summary: Book Challenge: Various books challenged for Sex
notes: After a TX Rep released a list of 850+ books that he claimed were potentially problematic, the district removed 400 books to be reviewed even though the District's policy says that access to challenged resources must not be restricted during the reconsideration process.  The district also removed some books without engaging in the district's challenge procedure

summary: Book Challenge: It's Perfectly Normal challenged for Sex
notes: The Holmen School Board voted to keep It's Perfectly Normal, a book for kids about puberty and sexual health, on its middle school's shelves after an appeal to have it removed.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer challenged for Sex
notes: After a challenge by a citizen of Pella, the Pella Public Library Board voted unanimously to keep the graphic autobiography Gender Queer shelved in the adult section of the library.

summary: Book Challenge: Out of Darkness and The Hate U Give challenged for Sex and Profanity
notes: Out of Darkness and The Hate U Give were removed from libraries after review committees recommended removal.

summary: Book Challenge: It's Perfectly Normal and In The Night Kitchen Removed for Sex
notes: It's Perfectly Normal, by Robie Harris; and In The Night Kitchen, by Maurice Sendak, were reportedly removed from a public library under pressure from local politicians, against the library's book challenge procedures.

summary: Book Challenge: Seven Books Challenged for "Inappropriate" Content
notes: A book review committee reviewed Me and Earl and the Dying Girl by Jesse Andrews; Forever for a Year by B.T. Gottfred; Jack of Hearts by Lev Rosen; All Boys Aren't Blue by George Johnson; The Breakaways by Cathy Johnson; The Nerdy and the Dirty by B.T. Gottfred; and Lawn Boy by Jonathan Evison, for "inappropriate" content.

summary: Book Challenge: Born a Crime Challenged for Violence, Profanity and Sex
notes: After a parent challenged Born a Crime by Trevor Noah, the school board voted to retain it.

summary: Book Challenge: To Kill A Mockingbird Challenged for Intolerance
notes: After a parent challenged To Kill A Mockingbird, a committee voted to remove it from the required reading list, but to keep it on an approved list for voluntary use by teachers.

summary: Book Challenge: Several Books Challenged for Sex
notes: Students spoke out at a school board meeting against the removal of Gender Queer, Traffick, Monday's Not Coming, and You and Me and Him.

summary: Book Challenge: Lawn Boy Challenged for Sex
notes: School officials in Wayzata, Minnesota, removed Lawn Boy by Jonathan Evison from the Wayzata High School library in violation of District regulations.

summary: Book Challenge: Out of Darkness Challenged for Sex
notes: Out of Darkness was removed from school libraries in Henrico County, VA - per media inquiry. Unclear if it was permanently removed, or removed pending the outcome of the challenge. Policy requires all challenges to be decided by the board, after recommendation by committee and Superintendent.

summary: Book Challenge: All Boys Aren't Blue, Gender Queer, and Me and Earl and the Dying Girl Challenged for Sex
notes: Although board regulations require that book challenges be adjudicated according to a specified process, board policy allows administrators to ignore regulations at their discretion. Hence, these books were removed without going through the challenge procedure.

summary: Event/Other Expression: Student Speech Censored for LGBTQ Content
notes: A 17-year-old student claimed that, after being selected as a featured student in a senior spotlight profile in a school-sponsored publication, he was told that what he wrote would not be published because he talked about his sexuality.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer Challenged for Sex
notes: The school board upheld the superintendent's decision to remove Gender Queer from school libraries, overruling the recommendation of a review committee.

summary: Book Challenge: I'm a Gay Wizard Challenged for Sex
notes: I'm a Gay Wizard was removed from library shelves pending the outcome of a challenge.

summary: Book Challenge: Lawn Boy and Gender Queer Challenged for Sex
notes: The Billings Public School Board voted to keep both Gender Queer and Lawn Boy on library shelves after a review committee recommended keeping the latter and removing the former.

summary: Book Challenge: Various Books Challenged for LGBTQ Content
notes: The mayor of Ridgeland, MS, threatened to withhold library funding unless the library removed LGBTQ+ books.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer Challenged for Sex
notes: The school board voted to retain Gender Queer in school libraries after it was challenged by a parent.

summary: Book Challenge: Beyond Magenta Challenged for Sex
notes: The school board voted to remove Beyond Magenta by Susan Kuklin from the high school library and restrict its access from the counseling office.

summary: Book Challenge: Various Books Challenged for Sex, Profanity
notes: After a parents' group filed challenges to 31 books, a district committee recommended removing one book from the elementary school curriculum, limiting the use of six others, and keeping the rest with no restrictions.

summary: Book Challenge: Lawn Boy Removed for Sex
notes: Lawn Boy was removed from a school library. District policy currently gives school principals discretion to remove books, but the district is considering amending that policy. NCAC provided them with our guidelines for book challenge procedures.

summary: Book Challenge: Maus Removed for Sex
notes: Board members voted unanimously to remove Maus from the curriculum because it contained swear words and a naked illustration. They did not follow the district's challenge procedures.

summary: Art/Display: Student Art Removed for Political/Social Views
notes: After a parent complained about an LGBTQ flag on the door of a fifth-grade teacher's classroom, an assistant principal noticed pieces of art students had created on their own time=E2=80=94not as part of an assignment=E2=80=94on Pride Week in October and ordered the teacher to take them down.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer, Out of Darkness and Lawn Boy Challenged for Sex
notes: The school board rejected a challenge to Gender Queer, Out of Darkness and Lawn Boy.

summary: Book Challenge: Dragonwings Removed for Intolerance, Profanity, Violence, and Drugs/Alcohol
notes: Dragonwings was removed from the 6th-grade curriculum after a review committee recommended its removal.

summary: Book Challenge: Jack of Hearts (and Other Parts) and If I Was Your Girl Challenged for Sex
notes: Two book challenges were terminated because proper procedures were not followed. There was no effort to resolve it informally before formal challenges were initiated.

summary: Book Challenge: The Girl Who Fell from the Sky Challenged for Sex
notes: Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools said it is looking into complaints about a novel that ninth-grade students are required to read.

summary: Book Challenge: Gender Queer Challenged for Sex
notes: The library board in Coppell, TX, deadlocked on whether to remove Gender Queer. A library committee had recommended keeping it.

summary: Book Challenge: The Hate U Give Challenged for Profanity
notes: The school board removed The Hate U Give from classes during a closed session in November. But after an outcry from parents, they reopened the discussion to the public and are now reassessing district policies. The book had never been adopted by the district. NCAC sent book challenge guidelines to the district.

summary: Book Challenge: Thirteen Reasons Why and Me and Earl and the Dying Girl Challenged for Sex and Dark Themes
notes: The Bixby Public Schools Board of Education voted unanimously to keep Thirteen Reasons Why and by a margin of 3-2 to keep Me and Earl and the Dying Girl in the wake of the challenge.

summary: Book Challenge: Various Books Removed for Sex
notes: School Superintendent asked middle and high school librarians to remove 16 books from school media center shelves for a review after receiving complaints about the books from the activist group County Citizens Defending Freedom. The group claimed that the books were "harmful to minors" under Florida law.
